title: Compiler cannot statically determinate when destructor for enum actually needed if `#[inline(never)]` used
body:
In libstd we have enums, that use `Box<T>` inside it's declaration, such as `borrow::Cow` and `io::Error`.
This applies not only to `Box <T>`, but also to types that has `impl Drop for T {}` and used in enums.

This code shows that compiler cannot analyze possible returned enums members and always adds destructor for `Drop` types.
```rust
#[inline(never)] //that's important
pub fn test() -> std::borrow::Cow<'static, str> {
    std::borrow::Cow::Borrowed("&'static str")
}

pub fn main() {
    drop(test());
}
```

Assembly:
```asm
example::test:
        mov     rax, rdi
        lea     rcx, [rip + .L__unnamed_1]
        mov     qword ptr [rdi + 8], rcx
        mov     qword ptr [rdi + 16], 12
        mov     qword ptr [rdi], 0
        ret

example::main:
        sub     rsp, 40
        lea     rdi, [rsp + 8]
        call    qword ptr [rip + example::test@GOTPCREL]
        cmp     qword ptr [rsp + 8], 0
        je      .LBB1_3
        mov     rsi, qword ptr [rsp + 24]
        test    rsi, rsi
        je      .LBB1_3
        mov     rdi, qword ptr [rsp + 16]
        mov     edx, 1
        call    qword ptr [rip + __rust_dealloc@GOTPCREL]
.LBB1_3:
        add     rsp, 40
        ret

.L__unnamed_1:
        .ascii  "&'static str"
```
The compiler could just skip this check in main. Instead of this it's use `__rust_dealloc`.
